original_title: Sri Lanka’s shares edge up in mid day
original_body_lines: ECONOMNYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares edged up in mid day trade on Tuesday, as the market anticipates the discussions with the International Monetary Fund to come to an end after March 20,2023, an analyst said.
“The overall sentiment is positive, the market is recovery mode on the IMF and profit taking is coming to an end with the renewed investor interest,” an analyst said.
All Share Price Index was up 0.89 percent or 84.66 points to 9,575.70, while the most liquid index S&P SL20 was up 0.28 percent or 7.94 points to 2,802.78.
Top gainers during mid day trade were HNB, Sampath Bank and NDB.

Financial indexes are seeing interest yet again due to the IMF approaching nearer to Sri Lanka as bilateral creditors have provided their assurances and Sri Lanka has implemented IMF backed policies for a 2.9 billion dollar loan, the analyst said.
The market generated a turnover of 1.1 billion rupees at 113o hours.

“The government has been settling construction debts through bonds issued and this repayment by the government has prompted some confidence for investors and we are seeing an upboost in the construction index,” the analyst said.

Howver, Power and Energy Counters have been loosing ever since Education Minister Susil Premajayantha signaled possible price cuts in fuel and electricity as low fuel demands have been seen, resulting on investors to speculate on lower revenues and returns pushing the index down.

“The Minister of Energy said by June the tariff will be revised again. We have to be patient. We have not become Venezuela or Argentina. We have not become a Pakistan. The inflation is coming down. The rupee that was at 362 against the USD is now at 307. Now it has further come down,” Premajayantha said. (Colombo/Mar14/2023)
